discussion.content:
Memorandum of understanding (MOU)—A preliminary or exploratory agreement to express an intent to work together. MOUs are usually intended to be relatively informal and not to act as binding contracts. MOUs almost always have clauses stating that the parties shall respect confidentiality, however.

Memorandum of agreement (MOA)—A formal agreement (or contract) that contains specific obligations rather than a broad understanding. If one party fails to fulfill its obligations, the other party will be able to seek redress under the terms of the agreement through the courts.

Note: Contract law is complex. It is possible for a document described as an "MOU" in a heading to create legally enforceable terms if the wording of the document establishes some sort of obligation to act, especially if it is in return for payment. The name of the agreement is not relevant—the terms are.

Reference: COM501B

questions.question_text: Which of the following agreement types is a non-contractual agreement between two or more parties and outlines each party's requirements and responsibilities?

questions.question_text:
A technician suspects that a system has been compromised. The technician reviews the following log entry:
WARNING- hash mismatch: C:\Window\SysWOW64\user32.dll
WARNING- hash mismatch: C:\Window\SysWOW64\kernel32.dll
Based solely ono the above information, which of the following types of malware is MOST likely installed on the system?
A technician wants to implement PKI-based authentication on an enterprise wireless network. Which of the following should the technician configure to enforce the use of client-side certificates?

discussion.content: The most secure EAP method is EAP-TLS, and it requires a certificate on the server and on each of the wireless clients. PEAP and EAP-TTLS require a certificate on the server, but not the client.

comments.content:
(EAP Transport Layer Security) An EAP method that requires a client-side certificate for authentication using SSL/ TLS.
PEAP is supported by Microsoft® as an alternative to EAP-TLS. It is simpler and cheaper to deploy than EAP-TLS because you only need a certificate for the authentication server.
When using PSK mode, users access the wireless network anonymously with a PSK or passphrase. This doesn’t provide authentication.

discussion.content: I'm going to go with C on this one, looks like someone mounted storage and copied to /tmp/1 and then copied to home directory which is against company policy, hence the policy violation.
"company has forbidden the use of external media" - which means User can't mount a media manually and violate policy. It has to be Malware.
Someone is mounting a drive to copy something... could be malware or could just be a music library... go with Policy Violation which is obvious.

Not really sure probably just stick with provided answer: B. The output is the Linux history command, which shows the last five commands and can be used as a tool to find intruders, if the attacker ran a “bad” command and forgot to remove, the history it will be there. 

psklll 1788 & 914 services have been known to support vulnerabilities, not always but reported. Another thing to note directory and temp folders are being created and something mounted and unmounted. seems suspicious behavior, but could be normal. The fact that this history command is being used, analyst is looking for something.

comments.content: How is it A policy violation?
The company's policy forbids the use of removable media. The commands seem to indicate that someone mounted a usb, which would violate that policy.

To many clues pointing to malware. "Someone" and the processes being killed is key in my view, looks like Malware. Also, "odd behavior" and files being installed in temp directory's. security analyst discovered Doesn't look like a misconfiguration to me, but what do I know. Wonder if CompTIA loves to be vague on a lot of there questions?

discussion.content:
Race condition means the system is loping or circling around with out ded end so the given answer is Right

Intrusive scans attempt to exploit a vulnerability when it is found. This can highlight the likely risk and impact of a vulnerability, but may also disrupt your operational systems and processes, and cause issues for your employees and customers — so use intrusive scanning with caution.
Is it not D - can anyone confirm?

The given answer is correct. An exploitation framework is a means of running intrusive scanning. An exploitation framework uses the vulnerabilities identified by a scanner and launches scripts or software to attempt to exploit selected vulnerabilities. This might involve considerable disruption to the target, including service failure, and risk data security.

comments.content: "During certain vulnerability scanning scenarios" Not attacks. It's between A and D. I'll go with provided answer.

yeah that actually makes more sense. i didn't realize the distinction of it being a vulnerability scan and not an attack. an intrusive scan can cause a system to react in unexpected ways because it's exploiting vulnerabilities. thank you

discussion.content: this question is similar to #946 and the answer was torn between race condition and buffer overflow but i chose race condition. correct me if i'm wrong.

questions.question_text: During certain vulnerability scanning scenarios, it is possible for the target system to react in unexpected ways. This type of scenario is MOST commonly known as:
